translation.text: Basant, First Mehl:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: The mind is deluded by doubt; it comes and goes in reincarnation.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: It is lured by the poisonous lure of Maya.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: It does not remain stable in the Love of the One Lord.

translation.text: Like the fish, its neck is pierced by the hook. ||1||

translation.text: The deluded mind is instructed by the True Name.

translation.text: It contemplates the Word of the Guru's Shabad, with intuitive ease. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: gur sabad bīchārē sahaj bhāi .1. rahāu .

translation.text: The holes of the body are worthless, if the mind is filled with such great desire for corrupt passions.

translation.text: It is like the elephant, trapped by its own sexual desire.

translation.text: It is caught and held tight by the chains, and beaten on its head. ||2||

translation.text: It is cursed and condemned in the Court of the Lord, without the Naam, the Name of the Lord.

text: ਤਾ ਕੈ ਜਾਤਿ ਨ ਪਾਤੀ ਨਾਮ ਲੀਨ ॥

translation.text: He has no class or honor, and no one even mentions his name.

transliteration.text: tā kai jāt n pātī nām līn .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: That person who lacks virtue - all of his pains and sorrows are his only companions. ||3||

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. text: ਮਨੁ ਚਲੈ ਨ ਜਾਈ ਠਾਕਿ ਰਾਖੁ ॥

translation.text: His mind wanders out, and cannot be brought back or restrained.

transliteration.text: man chalai n jāī thāk rākh .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. text: ਬਿਨੁ ਹਰਿ ਰਸ ਰਾਤੇ ਪਤਿ ਨ ਸਾਖੁ ॥

translation.text: Without being imbued with the sublime essence of the Lord, it has no honor or credit.

transliteration.text: bin har ras rātē pat n sākh .

translation.text: You Yourself are the Listener, Lord, and You Yourself are our Protector.

translation.text: You are the Support of the earth; You Yourself behold and understand it. ||4||

translation.text: When You Yourself make me wander, unto whom can I complain?

translation.text: Meeting the Guru, I will tell Him of my pain, O my mother.

translation.text: Abandoning my worthless demerits, now I practice virtue.

Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਸਭ ਮਹਿ ਏਕੋ ਕਿਛੁ ਕਹਣੁ ਨ ਜਾਇ ॥

translation.text: The One Lord is contained amongst all; nothing else can be said.

transliteration.text: sabh mah ēkō kish kahan n jāi .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: The Hukam of His Command pervades everywhere, and all merge in His Command.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: Pain and pleasure all come by His Will. ||7||

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਤੂ ਅਭੁਲੁ ਨ ਭੂਲੌ ਕਦੇ ਨਾਹਿ ॥

translation.text: You are infallible; You never make mistakes.

transliteration.text: tū abhul n bhūlau kadē nāh .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: Those who listen to the Word of the Guru's Shabad - their intellects become deep and profound.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: You, O my Great Lord and Master, are contained in the Shabad.

translation.text: O Nanak, my mind is pleased, praising the True Lord. ||8||2||
